content: The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 aims to make research findings accessible to the public through the internet, benefiting scientists, educators, and citizens. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 defines a "Federal agency" as an Executive agency under section 105 of title 5, United States Code. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies with research expenditures over $100,000,000 to develop a public access policy for research papers funded by the government. This policy includes submitting the author's final manuscript of research papers accepted for publication in peer-reviewed journals. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates Federal agencies to establish a public access policy for research papers funded by the government, requiring authors to submit their final manuscripts of papers accepted for publication in peer-reviewed journals. This policy also includes incorporating changes from the peer review process and replacing the final manuscript with the published version with publisher consent. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies to establish a public access policy for research papers funded by the government, including submitting final manuscripts of papers accepted for publication in peer-reviewed journals, replacing them with the published version with publisher consent, and providing free online public access to these manuscripts within 6 months. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates Federal agencies to ensure free online public access to final peer-reviewed manuscripts or published versions within 6 months, create an online bibliography linking to full texts, and preserve research findings in a digital repository. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies to provide free online public access to research papers, create an online bibliography linking to full texts, and preserve research findings in a digital repository. Federal research public access policies must ensure long-term preservation and free public access to published research findings in stable digital repositories maintained by the agency. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates Federal agencies to ensure free public access to research papers in digital repositories meeting specific criteria. Researchers employed or funded by the agency must comply with the policy, marking public domain works accordingly. The policy mandates that researchers employed or funded by Federal agencies mark public domain works as such when published and make them immediately available. It also requires the use of Government licenses for reproduction, publication, and release. The Federal research public access policy requires researchers to mark public domain works as such when published and make them immediately available. It also mandates the use of Government licenses for reproduction, publication, and release of final manuscripts for Federal purposes. The Federal research public access policy excludes certain materials from its requirements, such as laboratory notes and classified research. It also does not apply to authors who do not submit their work to journals or works that are rejected by journals. It does not apply to authors who do not submit their work to journals or works rejected by journals. Nothing in this Act affects rights under title 17 or 35, United States Code. Federal agencies must submit a report on their research public access policy to the Committee on Homeland Security by October 1 each year. Federal agencies must submit a report on their research public access policy to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate, the Committee on Government Reform of the House of Representatives, and any other relevant congressional committee by October 1 each year. Each report under this subsection must include a statement on the effectiveness of the Federal research public access policy in providing free online access to research papers funded by the Federal agency, along with a list of papers published in peer-reviewed journals reporting on federally funded research. The report must include an assessment of the Federal research public access policy's effectiveness in providing free online access to federally funded research papers, a list of papers published in peer-reviewed journals reporting on the research, a corresponding list of papers made available by the Federal agency due to the policy, and a summary of the time between public availability of each paper in a journal. The Federal agency must provide a report assessing the effectiveness of the research public access policy in offering free online access to federally funded research papers. This report should include a list of papers published in peer-reviewed journals, a corresponding list of papers made available by the agency, and a summary of the time between public availability of each paper in a journal and the online repository. The agency is required to make this information available to the public by posting it on their website.
